column11: Loverâ€™s Leap Waterfall is a beautiful and peaceful spot just a short drive from Nuwara Eliya town. The walk to the falls takes you through lush tea plantations, making the journey just as scenic as the destination. The waterfall itself is stunning, cascading from around 30 meters high into a quiet, green setting. The site is tied to a local legend about two lovers who leapt to their fate from this very spot, adding a sense of history and mystery to the visit. The path is relatively easy to access, but wearing comfortable shoes is recommended as it can be slightly uneven. This is a great stop if you want to enjoy nature, take in the views, and capture some beautiful photos away from the busy town. Itâ€™s not a large waterfall, but the charm of the area and the surrounding tea estates make it well worth a visit.

column8: A tale of star crossed lovers
column11: Lovers leap is a waterfall situated a couple of kms away from the Nuwara Eliya town.... it's not the most breathtaking and during dry seasons it would hardly have any water but it does have its own charm and it's own (rather sorrowful) tale... Backstory - According folklore a prince who lived in the area during ancient times fell in love with a village girl and when his parents opposed match, the ill fated lovers chose to jump to their death from the top of this waterfall on a full moon day rather than be seperated. Hence the name.... "Lover's leap"....... How to get there - There were so many conflicting reviews on how to get there and the level of difficulty in getting there.... This was our experience.. After reading many reviews we took the longer route (second option) shown on Google maps and that was to get to the Pedro tea factory. Just as you see the factory (coming from NE side) there is a left turn (carpeted road) to the estate managers bungalow ,as indicated on the turnoff. After about 200 meters down this road you get two left turns (at the same point). Our tuk driver took the upper left turn which was in terrible conditon with large pot holes. There are more turnoffs down this road but you always take the turnoff going up.... after about 10-15 mts you will get to a large tree from where the path turns into a footpath... from there it's only about 250 meters to the waterfall. Halfway through path you come to a gate and fence seeming fencing off a makeshift kovil. You take the right turn next to the gate and after about 50 meters the road again forks into two from which you take the lower route to the left. ( I read on reviews that the locals will offer to take you to the top of the waterfall. So I assume the right turn off would lead to the top of the waterfall. But there were no locals in sight on the day we visited, so we didn't explore any further.) The walking part was pretty easy. It wasn't flat land but nothing particularly strenuous. We also noticed that there was a concrete paved road down below coming almost upto the waterfall. This may have been the lower road in the first turnoff, but then again non of the tuk drivers coming to falls seemed to take this route. There was enough water flow to make it worthwhile when we visited, but it may not warrant a visit during dry season.

Loverâ€™s Leap Falls is a beautiful waterfall a short drive from town, near the Pedro Tea Factory. The initial section up from the main road can be walked, but we opted to take a tuk-tuk, because e were tight for time. You first cross through the tea plantation with excellent views of Nurawa Eliya, before reaching a forest path (where tuk-tuks will park. Our excellent, considerate and thoughtful driver Jagan accompanied us, picking wild flowers for our daughter and explaining interesting details along the way. He also ensured our son was safe when he wanted to explore closer to the falls (where I was a bit concerned about slipping in my sandals). We thought the ride was definitely worth the roughly $8US (1500 SKR), although it was rough and taxed the tuk-tuks lower gears. It had also drizzled all morning so it was muddy and slippery, which this option allowed us to avoid. The path to the falls is picturesque and the view at the end is striking with the cool spray from the cascading waters misty your face. Took about an hour round trip, but was one of the highlights of our time in Nurawa Elyria.

It can be easily skipped if your itinerary is full.

It was an impromptu decision to go to this location. Our driver took us to the locality, from where we took a tuk tuk for half the ride up amidst the tea plantations. Since the path is full of stones and very narrow, normal cars cannot go up, however tuk tuks can easily access the place. For serious hikers, they can go for the climb all the way till the falls. En route, the view is enthralling, with team plantations all around and if the weather is on your side, there is little mist and clouds. As we went in December, we continued to experience rainfall throughout our journey. Once the tuk tuk parked at it's last accessible spot, we took a short hike up (around a kilometre). Ensure to wear proper hiking shoes as because of the waterfall, the area is wet, with lots of small streams flowing, making the path slippery. There are also loose stones and wet ones, so shoes with a good grip will help. If you have not climbed before, be careful of your footing, however for most part, its a fairly easy climb. Also be prepared to get wet! Needless to say, the water from the waterfall will get you soaked. Mind you, we were just on one side of the waterfall and not in its way, however the pressure sends water sprays that soak you completely. Some of us went prepared and were fine... others like me felt we jumped into the water :) Its a fantastic view and very rejuvenating to be in the midst of nature and I really enjoyed it. With the cold and wet weather of Nuwara Eliya, note that clothes DO NOT dry easily, unless you have heaters or fans.

Took a tuk tuk, walk and climb to this area. The view was amazing, the water from the water fall is cool when standing there and watching the water pour down from it. The first time i ever see a water fall at close distance

The waterfall is really beautiful and the walk up to the waterfall is not too difficult. Take a left at the blue water tank and keep heading straight until you see signs. Mostly dirt roads with a few steep parts at the end of the trail. Absolutely a must do!

A must-do in any travel to Nuwara Eliya is the tea plantations. Learn how tea came to Sri Lanka, sip different tea,  consider a purchase and explore the landscape. Learn now the name lover's leap came about.
this is the very good waterfall to admire with a 2km hiking towards the location. its the bird view of the city too see the height mountain range also the other provincial change too.

Over 30 mtrs high, you can sit on a rock opposite and feel the spray in your face, but be careful, them rocks can be slippery when wet.

There is a legend of the sorts with this serene fall about a prince and his forbidden lover. Sources though not available to validate it. Curiously is the fact that why then it was named "Lover's Leap" instead of some Sinhalese version of it. The fall can be reached by a easy hike through Pedro Estate starting from Boralanda junction. (2km).
Little away from the main road. Has a road and path to up. Nice view from up. Beautiful waterfall You are walking alone nice tea plantations
Beautiful waterfall fall. Little narrow road is there to reached to the place. And also need to walk in middle of tea state. Can go to closer to the fall.
This is a another beautiful water fall around here. You have to walk a bit from the main road to get close  to the water fall.

We used a tuk tuk most of the way to the falls as it was very hot and the road was both steep and rough. Plenty walked it but I can't comment on how difficult it is. The falls are lovely but not overly massive. There's a flat rock to stand on at the base to admire the waterfall and plunge pool. It's not going to change your life or anything but its worth it for the lovely views of Nuwara Eliya and the cool breeze you get up there.
You have to walk to the waterfall. Not far and not difficult. It is worth a visit. Such a nice story about the waterfall and You can get quite close to it.
Worth the visit despite the windy roads towards the leap.  The weather whilst we were visiting was not the best but we were determined to drive up the narrow road leading to the Lover's Leap.
We didnâ€™t walk there because of weather but stopped at the oak ray wood shop for a view from their rooftop. Gorgeous.
Managed to snap a picture of the fall from a distance. Due to lack of time did not trek to the fall. As usual better to go early morning where is comfortable and cooler.
Saw from a distance- didn't have time to trek up close. Looked fine from a distance- you can possibly skip unless you've lots of time to trek or very very fond of waterfalls

This is a very beautiful waterfall about 1.2 Km from Uda-Pussellawa main road. About 4 Km from Nuwara Eliya town. You don't have pay anyone to visit here, its a Free attraction. You don't need a tour guide, you can explore this place by your self. The path from Uda-Pussellawa road to the waterfall is narrow and also there is no parking place. So avoid taking cars or vans beyond main road. We parked the car in Uda-Pussellawa main road (near by a shop) and walk. Its really a nice walk, through the tea plantation. Please wear suitable shoes, some parts through the tea plantation is bit difficult to climb. It was raining on the day we visited there, so we decided not to go all way to the top of the fall or the bottom, as it is bit slippery.

The road to this beautiful water fall was unique and adventurous. There was tea estates and lot of uneven terrain to travel and at the end it was all worth it. I would recommend for those who go to the water fall please do not walk down the rocks to get closer unless you are with a professional tour guide as the rocks can be very slippery.
Wonderful fall with beautiful view . Nice place to click images . Clean place and nice for family. superb
Best place for Trekking and chillout. This place found as two lovers jump to suicide from waterfall top. best place to relax with water breeze.

...probably because like the lover, your expectations takes a jump (down) when you see this. A little underwhelming to see it - but maybe because we didn't really go up close. Yet another waterfall to see in the region. I'd just say to stay in the car and get to your destination. Avoid this, unless you're a waterfall-phile.

Beautiful waterfall in picturesque surroundings. Turn to view the falls then turn for a wonderful view of local village and villagers doing their daily chores. A short walk out of town but very well worth the trip amoungst the cows, chickens and local houses. Unfortunately rubbish is a problem though.

Pretty waterfall. We walked up from the Pedro Tea Factory and it was a nice 20/30 minute hike through the tea plantations. On the way back we walked through the roads to town and it was nice to see all the small flower and food crops growing on people's properties.

It is a nice waterfall. It will run in full flow when there are rains to Nuwara Eliya. On our way back from piduruthalagala we visited this place. Not very far from town only 6.1kms from town. You can use either upperlake road or Nuwara Eliya  - Udapussellawa Road. After travelling about 5kms you have to turn to Lovers leap road.
Just park up and take in the view, you can also see from the train from Kandy. Or you wish you can drive to the falls and walk up. We saw from the visitor area opposite.

We did a hike up to the falls. The hike was good and the waterfall was alright. It wasn't mind-blowing or anything, mostly because the viewing area was in an odd place, too close to the falls. There's no proper viewing area for the falls, which may be a good thing as the whole area still looks quite natural and untouched. All in all, your experience depends on how many visitors are in the area at the time you're there. If there's too many people, you'll feel rushed to leave the area.

I took a walk from the town itself where Google Maps suggested. Had to walk around 3kms from the town but it's really worth if you are interested in sight seeing. Through small trail you can reach closer to the falls and on way back I chose the path towards Pedro tea estate. Many trails are available towards top of falls as it seems but unfortunately i couldn't try them up as I was running out of time. Good to spend some time hearing the music of the water....!! :)
We decided to walk to the falls following the road, which proved enjoyable. The falls themselves are very nice; however we were not able to locate a clear path up to the top, which was disappointing.

We cycled here form Pedro Tea Estate and then walked the last few hundred metres. It's a fun if hot walk walk (not too difficult but a little slippery on the very steep bits). We were rewarded with the beautiful falls. We paddled and drank the fresh clear, cold water. You can sit on the rocks and feel and feel as though you are in the falls. Definitely worth a visit.

There are several routes up to the falls. My driver took me to a village part of the way up the hill. From there the path was fairly steep. The falls were higher than I expected, the area clean and green. On the way down we got a bit lost - trying to take a less steep route - but found our way through the tea plantations and fields in the end.

Not the fall, its the path leading to fall thats fantastic. The hike takes you through the tea plantation and some great landscape on the way. Many people were taking tuk tuk up to a point, i think hike along the way is great way to enjoy this.

I had already seen two lovely waterfalls in the hill country so i was not too impressed with Lover's Leap as it was much smaller than Ravana or Bambarakanda. It is less than an hour's walk from the town center but the final few hundred meters is up a steep path. Apparently prince found a sweetheart but his people did not like her so they committed suicide jumping from the falls.

There is no support in this way. And without guidance dont go. This waterfall is a drinking water reservoir. So everywhere kindly adviced, dont pollute this place. Dont bath in this place due to this reason. You can walk towards this waterfall through the pathways in tea plantations. It is really nice experience. This is nice place for photography. In rainy season please be careful because slippery place There is a nice legend around this waterfall. King of this area had fallen love with a girl near village of this area. Then his father opposed it and they both went top of the waterfall on full moon poya day and jumped. So this waterfall named as " Lovers leap"
This Waterfall is close to Pedro tea factory which is why my partner and I chose to go here. For anyone who wishes to visit the waterfall a little heads up it is a bit of a trek uphill.

This nice waterfall is just a short ride outside Nuwara Eliya by tuck tuck or bus. It's across the main road from Pedro Tea Estate.  There is a big sign pointing you in the  direction. You don't need a guide to find it. The walk to the fall is easy  and pretty, and takes you through tea fields on a gravel road. Shoes are better than slippers for this walk, and  almost everybody will be able do it. Most will even find the walk quite easy. The waterfall itself is fine, but you can find even bigger ones in this part of the country. All in all Lovers Leap is a fine morning or afternoon walk.
A beautiful waterfall with a tragic name. The views are spectacular when you climb to the top. The path is not the easiest to go along.
Starting from the main road and travel about 20 minutes anyone can visit this amazing place. if its hard to walk you can get a tuk tuk for a fair price. Beautiful hidden place.
Its beautiful surrounded by tea plantation. We just stopped on the main road to have a look on our way back to Nuwara. It was beautiful.

A lovely view, especially if you climb to the top of the falls, however the falls themselves were just ok, nothing spectacular. We didn't have time to walk up as we went after a visit to the tea plantation late afternoon. The falls themselves are visually unimpressive so if you're not going for the views don't waste your time.
On the main road, about an hours drive away from Nuwara. One can take photos and then move on. It is on the main road hence crossing the road needs attention.

This is a terrific attraction. Free entry and sensational views. We visited the day after some rain which was good however even with little water the view would still be worth the hike. The highlight is going right up to the top of the falls, this is a very steep and slippery section and not clearly marked. It took us 1.5 hours to reach the top from the centre of Nuwara-eliya. We then got a tuk tuk back into town for just 200rs.
This is my first time to come in this place and it was really really great experience. Every single things here in Sri Lanka ðŸ‡±ðŸ‡° I really appreciate.

Around 10 - 20 min hike, u will be rewarded with the spectacular view of the waterfall. My muscle was not helping me to go faster to the view area due to muscle pain after hiked up the Adamâ€™s Peak. After few minutes climbing.. all the pain goes away when you see the great view.

My trip to Horton was cancelled due to the weather so I came here.  It took less than 1.5 hours to walk to the waterfall from the centre of town.  There's a sign on the road opposite Pedro tea factory, then it's an uphill walk along a road through the scenic tea fields, with only the final 50 metres being more like a hiking track.  The rain meant that the falls were going strong and you could stand in the spray underneath.  You can climb over rocks to get different views but be careful if they're wet.  It was all nicer than the walk up Single Tree Hill but there will be a lot more people here. Then you can go up a path behind the info sign to get to the top of the falls.  This one is challenging - the correct path isn't always obvious, you have to climb at points, and you have to be extremely careful if it's wet.  Do it if you're adventurous and have good shoes.  There are good views from the top and you'll probably be alone with the falls.  Allow at least 45 minutes return.
Well worth the walk to this waterfall and several great places to take some great photos. Nice place to simply take in the view.

The turn-off to the Pedro Tea Estate is better sign-posted, but the road to Lover's Leap starts just opposite. We were immediately approached by a tuk-tuk driver who declared the road impassable with a regular vehicle.  He was partially right.  Some 200 m further up the road it does get bad.  Some vehicles with higher clearance still drive up that way, as do tuk-tuks.  We walked, as the tea-landscape is pleasant and the trail makes for an easy hike. About half-way up the trail, even tuk-tuks stop and you have to walk the last ten minutes or so.  You are rewarded by the sight of the waterfall, which is by no means massive, but a refreshing sight.
this waterfall is situated in nuwara eliya. we have to walk few miles by walking  through nice tea field . it is very beautiful to be there.
Not too far from the town proper. We did not end up hiking all the way to the top of the waterfall - it was extremely steep and quite wet. A nice short hike to get out of town.

It's a small trek to the water falls. It's about a 10 mins walk towards the waterfalls. The view is good. No entrance fees. Our tuk tuk driver took us to the waterfalls. Better to go with someone to guide you through the trails to the waterfalls. Saves time.

This place was so beautiful. We got dropped off at the bottom of a little hill and walked through tea plants to get there. It is off to your left as you begin your walk. You pass a beautiful little chalet hotel and the views from up top are incredible, including two large temples. We had a little boy who walked with us the whole way to show us the way. He was kind, but demanded money at the end. Please just find your way yourself, it is easy to see the road that you get on after tea plants and go left and follow the well marked trail. Totally worth it and my five year old and eight year old loved it. Beautiful way to spend an hour or so. You could even get a drink or snack at the little chalet on the way back.
Lovers Leap waterfalls was like 200 meters from Paul's Wood Cabana, where we were staying. The waterfall is very easy to access. Nuwareliya is a bit cold so warm clothes is recommended for the hike.

The first part of the walk is not attractive because you have to go along the street but when you enter side street everything changes. You walk up through the village and then amazing tea fields. Final stage is through the forest. Waterfall is picturesque. The whole way from city centre is around 5 km. If you don't want to cover everything on your feet you may take tuktuk or local bus.   The attraction is free.
We visited here during our stay in Nuwara Eliya. Reaching out to the base of this place is quite a challenge but its all worth it when you reach there. a Must try!

Reading some of the comments here we negotiated with a driver from the city center for a to and fro trip for 800. The ride up was bumpy and fun but also full value for money as there were lovely views along the way. There is a short 5-7 min hike over natural forest terrain before you reach the viewing point with breathtaking views of the water falls. Along the way you can dip your hands or take a sip (depending on how strong your gut it and how adventurous you are) from the numerous small streams with crystal clear cool water trickling down. Donâ€™t be fooled though by the tuk tuk guys who tell all sort of stories about the distance and difficulty. The distance is no more than 5 km from city center and difficulty is what you pay 750-800 rs which is far the normal tariff for such a distance. All in all a couple of hours well spent and well worth a trip in clear weather.

The point of view is nice, you can see the city. The fall is quite tall and refreshing. There are two tracks to reach it : the first one starts juste before the little bridge coming from town center on the road below the fall (steep and some climbing), the other one is easy and you walk in tea plantations and access Pedro tea factory from there.

Did this on our tour with our wonderful guide it is a must if your travelling this way you wonâ€™t be disappointed And real good for some amazing pictures

A pleasant early morning walk through the tea plantations with great views over the city of Nuwara Eliya. After 30 minutes or so you then have these clean water falls to view. Surrounded by lush bush and the bird song nearby adds to the drama of the visit.
But you need a guide there are some local people can help and come with you. Going up to the highest point of waterfall takes 3 or more hours but I recommend that don't lose it

If you have planned for Pedro Tea Factory, then this is a must visit, as it is very near. A small hike up the hill and you will find the amazing views of the Fall. We were there on a rainy day, so the fall was amazing. can't comment about dry season.

though good view.. 10.minutes hiking on rocky track.. rikshaw might ask for 1500..do go for discount..we got there for 800..after that 10 minutes of walking view was beautiful..so is rest of nuwara eliya.. you may miss it and go for doven and clairs water fall..or ramboda waterfall

I highly do not recommend this place . it is nothing but a little of water falling. see the photo I attached . the car also cannot take you there , while you need a tuck-tuck and to pay around 2000 rubies for nothing
Hard to reach the waterfalls, you need 30 to 40 minutes. The view is nice. We didn't found tuk tuk going up , only going down

This is a very pleasant walk through tea plantations to a beautiful waterfall. Unlike many of the attractions in the area it was remarkably uncrowded, which was a joy. The falls are lovely and there is a good view once you get there.
Nice easy walk that was much less busy than other places that I have visited. Can go walking off the track and walk directly to the water fall through the tea fields.

Walk from the main road, don't take a tuktuk! The views over the tea plantations are great. Falls are okay, but it's the complete trip that makes it worthwhile visiting. 1,5 hour in total. Nice photos from women working at the plantation.

After the tea factory we walk to this waterfall, we had bad weather, but it was still worth it! You will have a nice view over the city and it was amazing with all the clouds! In one time is clear and all the clouds are gone, looks so amazing! Also the waterfall is amazing!

The hiking is really pleasant and you can do it before or after you do the Pedro Tea factory visit. You can also enjoy some great views of the surroundings and the tea plantings around Nuwara Eliya. Note that the pathways are not very well indicated, but you should find it easily.

While many may disagree with my review, I am sticking to what I am writing here. The fall is beautiful and the walk up the fall is well worth it. Do not attempt to take the tuk tuk up the hill. Go and enjoy the nature and you will be amazed at what you see. The climb can be quite tiring but it is absolutely well worth it. Go for it folks.

Anyone who gives this natural creation a poor review has no idea what they're talking about. Take the bus here and walk up the hill. Don't take a tuktuk. The walk is nice but there were loads of kids on the way up who were spread in packs... First lot tried to sell us some narcotic substances and followed us for a bit much to the discomfort of my other half. Further up there were more who would ask for money and shadow you. Have your wits about you here The falls are nice. Peaceful. A nice rock.to lay on. If you're ballsy, climb higher and stand on the higher rocks. Nice place and well worth it.

The hike up to Lover's Leap has stunning views. You can take a tuk-tuk up to specific point though the wrong tuk-tuk will struggle to go up the hill! The waterfall itself isn't as spectacular from close up but that's just my opinion

We went towards the end of day. Tuk Tuk took us up the hill, through an uneven road. Once up, we had to trek for a while. The view was ok. Maybe we had seen a lot during the day, so view was not as great as the reviews mentioned. The falls were also average. Not a lot of flow. Overall it was ok, For senior citizens, my parents are 65+, so my mother could not make it. Father is fitter and made it. So, if parents are with you, see if you want to take them with you.

Be aware that distance between the main road to waterfall is just less than 1.5 km,when we asked about the waterfall way the drivers asked us 15000sr and told us its far far from the main road (8km) they said that's impossible to get there by walk!but I just checked the google map and ask our host! Be careful about tuk tuks they'll cheat you if you don't have enough information! Also the way to the waterfall was really really great we pass the tea fields and amazing views above,don't mind miss the way! And an other important point! Don't care about boys who will ask you money during the way just ignore them and keep walking!
We parked our car near the road and walked about 2 Km.waterfall is covered with tea plantations and trees.

If you just have only one afternoon to visit around Nuwara Eliya before going to Horton Plain next morning, Lover's Leap Falls is a perfect choice. I arrived Nuwara at 1.30pm and took a rest in my hostel (Lake View Holiday Home) till 3pm. The tuktuk driver offered me a tour package for 2 people to visit Lover's Leap Falls and tea factory for 1000Rs from our hostel (after bargain). I can tell that Lover's Leap Falls is really amazing, after tuktuk took us to the hill, we walked about 10 min to the fall. From the fall, we could see the whole picture of Nuwara Eliya and enjoyed the blowing wind, fresh air, and feel like time just stands still for a moment. This moment is memorable and priceless to me. After that, we went to the tea factory that was not so far away. To visit around factory, we paid 200Rs/person for visiting around and for the guider. If you dont want to visit around
Beautiful views, worth the climb we took a tuktuk up and otherwise long steep walk, watch out for begging children, which is actually against theaw in Sri Lanka.
This is a worthwhile and nice walk. You can look out over the tea plantations and see the waterfall. We walked back to town and took the bus out but you can also take a tuk tuk.
The falls is very nice and looks fantastic. It is cascading from a  great height and looks very lovely..

We walked to the falls from the other side of the lake which was about 5k and took about 1.5 hours.   It makes a very scenic walk and you can take a slightly different route to the taxis although some parts are fairly steep and take lots of water. The views are great and on the way back down we caught the local bus back to town which was rs 30 for both of us. Nice experience.

We took a tuk-tuk from Nuwara Eliya, overpriced, as it is another and easier way to visit the falls. Easy hike and nice falls, but not spectacular. We took a shortcut back and passed lovely small houses and gardens before we reached the main road and got  a tuk-tuk back to Nuwara Eliya. It is also possible to go by bus, but tuk-tuk is more convenient.

My girlfriend and I really enjoyed the hike to Lovers leap (short, about 15 minutes) and enjoyed taking in the views. It advertises that you need to take a tuk tuk, but it is easy to take a car pretty close to the trail head and walk up.

This a pretty little fall, and the walk is quite pleasant. Plan it for the morning when it's clear. We took a tuk tuk and the driver walked up with us and told us about the area. You'll pass tea plantations on the walk and bring a little money to tip tea pickers if you want to photograph them. They recently went on strike and got a 50% raise: they now earn enough money to purchase one small tin of mutton or a bottle of beer a day for 8 hours of work picking 60 pounds of tea rain or shine on steep hillsides.

We walked up to the waterfall from the town (easy to follow Google Maps through the outskirts of town. Nice area and we were all alone as it was raining cats and dogs! We could imagine the views on a sunny day must be pretty extraordinary. Not many indications when there, would have been nice to understand more.
Great view for pictures only. If you are in your way from Kandy to Nuwara eliya do not miss it. You have to stop and tage pictures.  GREAT VIEW

Nice waterfalls, but there is no proper road to the same.Also, the tuk-tuk will only take you to a certain point, beyond that you need to walk.Advisable to go in groups and the place is not very safe for children (safety wise)

We took a tuk-tuk from Pedro Tea Factory and Plantation (750 Rupees return) to get to and from the falls. The is a little walk at the top and not too strenuous to get to the falls which are not that spectacular but nice to view as is the vista from the falls across the valley. Younger people walked up and down and some took a tuk-tuk up and walked down.

The waterfall itself isn't too special. Not much water in the dry season. The way to the waterfall is a quite nice walk through the tea fields. You also can combine your visit here with a tour at Pedro's tea factory.
A nice waterfall that actually provides drinking water to the town. Don't listen to the tuk tuk drivers on the main road, it's only about 1.8km to the waterfall (although the path is quite steep).

we loved the trip to the fall , we took a tuk tuk and payed 1500 roepia for 1 tuk tuk - the small car did with us 15 minutes and then we walked for another 15 minutes to the faal. Lovers leap is a beautifull place, nearby you can see the tea factory and the peak of the highest mountain in Sri Lanka
Lovely site to see to see the water guessing down the mountain side wonderful scenery lots of people taking photos and monkeys looking for food

If you want to run from crowds and enjoy a piece of nature with great views over Pedro tea plantations go for it. You can come by Tuktuk very close or just walk from the main road by yourself which is better!

Web took the bus from Nurwa Eliya station cost 50 lkr going out and 24 coming back! Still ridiculously cheap. The bus conductor will tell you where to get off to find the path which is clearly marked. We got off at Pedro tea factory where we took some great photos of the tea terraces and reservoir. Walking up to the falls is not difficult although going right up to the top may be far more challenging  (we couldn't see the way to do this and weren't equipped anyway). The Lonely Planet guide mentioned this walk near the Pedro tea factory.  Make sure you don't enter the factory before looking for the start of the walk.  On our first attempt we headed down the hill from the factory and ended up at a dam.  In hindsight that was pretty dumb, since you usually need to climb to see a waterfall!  The start of the walk is actually well signposted from the main road and, not surprisingly, you need to go uphill. The walk is through plantations, and is not taxing.  When you reach a temple, you head up a small track and quickly come upon the waterfall.  It was not flowing heavily when we were there (Jan). For us, this was a nice way to do a bit of exercise and see the view before heading off on a drive to Kandy.

From where the car stops, it's a 10-15 minute walk that takes you through a local neighborhood, tea plants and other plantations common in this high-altitude Sri Lankan rural community. The fall itself is at its ebb in December, which is when we visited, but it still offers spectacular views of Nuwara Eliya. Lovers Leap is the main source of water for the entire Nuwara Eliya valley, so visitors are asked to be considerate of the water and not contaminate it. The name Lovers Leap kind of betrays the legend: a prince fell in love with a beautiful maiden living in the valley but his father opposed the union, so he took his beloved and together they leapt to their tragic demise, their love forever immortalized by the folly of their youth and a waterfall that is visited by many from far and wide.

I'm hind sight it worked out well as the walk up there would have taken quite a while and all the views were at the top. Once up the top the views of the local valleys were awesome. This place offers a very nice view, good Food and a nice garden surrounds the Restaurant. A good place for a rest.
The waterfalls were OK, but the walk through the countryside was lovely. Combine with visit to Pedro tea factory, and it makes a great morning

This is definetely my most favourite site in entire N'Eliya, and I wouldn't mind visiting there forever. The lover's leap waterfall is located inside a tea estate - you have to park your vehicle inside the estate and walk/hike for about 2km, which is not quite an easy walk, however, the destiny is perfectly worth it. The two times I visited here, it was not crowded like most other waterfalls in N'Eliya, so you are kind of stepping in your private tranquility. One time, we met two foriegners who were just lying and relaxing on a large rock beneath the waterfall, who had been there for hours!!! I would say, it's quite small compared to other waterfalls, however the beauty and its surrounding lives up to it. If you are really carefull, you could get close - i mean really close to the water fall, carefuly stepping on the rocks. There's one place where you can even climb halfway to the waterfall and actually get behind it. I had been eager to try this, but never got the chance. Perhaps next time :) In short, if you are in Nuwaraeliya, this is one fairyland of a place which you should not miss.

A really beautiful place to visit, there's a hotel at the top the drivers take all visitors to as a stop.  You can walk down to the base of the waterfall down a narrow path and stop for lunch on the way back up in the hotel.  A decent buffet curry for the price.

A very interesting place to expedite as hiking but not suitable for family with young ones. To reach the place, the vehicle has to be parked on a place and have to climb by foot. The climbing is very interesting as the sun shines in a pleasant cool weather for around 1.5 km. We climbed with the child as much as we could and returned when we encountered some high cliffs which was not possible with a toddler. However we met so many people with fresh vegetables and flowers planted in their gardens and had conversations. I would recommend this place for those interested in hiking as an early morning exercise.
there are many falls in the area, but somehow this one was prettier, more pleasant for the sight. We had lunch in a nearby restaurant with unique views to the falls.

It is a very very long journey to the words end point.You have to walk 16 Kms and that too at toughest terrain I have seen for walking. you have to walk through natural trails made by the flow of water in the mountain . It was worth going at the end and enjoyed the view.
It's an attractive spot with a decent waterfall. The road that goes up to the falls crossing tea fields is also nice.

The waterfall is easily reachable from Nuwara Eliya. It was really beautiful and it served to us as a substitute for other famous waterfalls that we did not have time to visit. The view of the town is also worth it.
When raining time it gives somewhat lonely feeling when you see it through mist. In the mountain range of Piduruthalaagala.

good casual walk through the plantations where you can see the ladies picking away. very beautiful if you can get it on a non-rainy day. won't take you more than an hour or 2. ask a local for the romantic story behind the waterfall's name.
Was a good one. Easy to go near by but not suggested to take bath.the view of the city from here is grear too. Easy to reach from the city.

Great hike, make sure you go all the way to the top of the falls, theres a huge flat rock with a great view thats perfect for a picnic. Protip: stock up on bubblegum at the minimart, as youre bound to get hassled by kids in the tea fields asking for chocolate or money. Gum makes a great substitute. Walking from pedros tea house, it takes maybe 20 mins to get to the falls. The scramble to the top is safe, but requires your hands to make it up, and takes probably another 20 mins. The 3 mile walk back into town is not bad either, you get a nice glimpse into local life, and pretty much everyone will smile and say hello. Overall the hike is a great alternative for those not wanting to burn a full day and 4000rs to do worlds end.

Even with a tuk-tuk for part of the journey there is still a lot of uphill walking (with significant drop-offs for vertigo sufferers). But well worth persevering. The viewing area is not large and you will get damp from the spray

Absolutely terrific walk - it takes very little time from the Pedro tea factory (if you are lazy you can always get a three wheeler from town to the tea factory). The waterfall is beautiful and the walk takes a little over half an hour. Thoroughly recommend.

Walking up to Lover's Leap fall was tough but very exciting. It took us about 45 minutes - 1 hour to climb up the Lover's Leap fall in Hawa Eliya, Nuwara Eliya. Breathtaking view of the city from top of fall. It is worth a visit.
You can enjoy the best cup of tea in Nuwareliya at Pedro and visit this place. There is legend behind this which is related by the staff.

Our driver took us on a wrong turn up the hill, and we found ourselves stopping at a point, from where it was a subtantial climb to the falls. However, enroute, we met this tea plantation worker, who was helpful guided us by the shortest route to the falls. Breathtaking views of the valley from the hill. a small shiva temple at the bottom of the falls, and the fall isnt as big as the ravana falls, but quite an eye pleaser.

It takes a total 1 hour there and back from Pedros. The trek takes you through the tea plantations where you see the Tamil workers busy in the fields. The walls are beautiful and you get a nice view of the city and the mist against the mountains. Definitely worth a visit (and unlike most things in Sri Lanka for foreigners - it's free!)

As soon as the Tuk Tuk stopped at the top of the hill, you have the stunning views of the Nuwara Eliya and the waterfall is infront of you! Now starts the beautiful journey towards fall! Go as close as possible. A good point for taking lovely pictures; Nuwara Eliya as backdrop!
This is a great waterfall, up a ~3km track opposite the turn off to the Pedro Tea factory. I highly recommend going up and having a look. The walk up and back took us about an hour.

It is right off the pretty tea gardens of Nuwara Eliya. It is a straight vertical fall and you got to enjoy it from a distance, don't think you can go close. There was no one when we visited last year, strange as it is a pretty sight and one can enjoy a few moments there.
Nice view of the area too.  Good place to picnic too! Need a 4 wheel vehicle to get there. Picturesque Can view tea pickers in the field on the way up too.

Lots of local families with children were enjoying splashing about in the cool water on the hot and humid day we were there. There's a lovely walk and great photo opportunities; the scenery in this area is beautiful and there are many tea factories in the vicinity where you can learn how tea is processed from the leaves- which are picked once a week by Tamil ladies. It's hard work, and we learned that they pick on average of 20 kilos of leaf tips per day to earn the princely sum of 6 dollars. It makes you appreciate how much hard work goes into making the cup of tea that cup of tea that we so easily make and enjoy.

The waterfall is a pleasant sight, but I think the true champion is the lovely winding track through the tea fields to access the Lovers Leap. Very scenic indeed. Enjoy the walk itself up to waterfall, and take a cool drink and snack to enjoy whilst at the destination.
We walked up the hill and really enjoyed it.  The waterfall itself wasn't truly amazing but the walk was great.
We wlaked from the city centre of Nuwara Eliya- it was difficult to find but nice:) From this place you can walk to Pedro tea plant factory- excellent views and great tea!
A pleasant walk though the tea plantations to a very high waterfall. Not really worth a major effort to see it but a nice enough waterfall if you have time on your hands in Nuwara Eliya

nice waterfall which is located in a quite calm and peaceful area. the waterfall itself is really nice and the view of the city from the waterfall area is just brilliant. a must visit place if you travel to Nuwara-Eliya.
The natural beauty of the falls is intriguing and beguiling.  Every turn you can catch a vision of the water flowing across the boulders.

Lovers Leap was so hostorical place !!! Its Ã¤ good walk before you reach this place buy its worth the falls was not to high bit what i like is the story behind this place,,, its so touching .. its Good enough for hiking .... Love this place.

We took a tuktuk, which was a good idea because it was raining. The track up to the carpark is rough, but the tuktuk managed it okay. The walk from the carpark to the falls is about 500metres. It's a pretty easy walk, then a slightly steeper climb to the base of the falls. Very peaceful, wonderful view of the town, looking over the tea plantations. Our tuktuk driver charged us 1000Rp for the return trip from town, including his 30minute wait in the carpark.
It's Free, nice 3Km walk to the site, there are few ways to climb it. Asked you local guide or hotel about more information.

The water fall isn't much, but still a nice up hill walk.  Only gets hard if you want to actually get up to lovers leap.  Takes about 1 1/2 return.  Little shade on way, so be prepared with sunscreen and water.

Turn near Pedro tea factory moving upwards towards this fall, closely to Nuwara Eliya and it's not a difficult terrain to cover. Cars, vans could go up I've seen even tuk tuks, small climb about  150 meters towards the waterfall passing through a local temple, best when it's the rainy season if not the fall is not at it's best as the feeder water source is not great when it's dry. You can picnic and also there is a local water tap where most visitors take a bath etc. Be considerate and leave nothing behind...

The waterfall itself is nice enough and a good place to chill for a while. Also well worth it is the way up right through the tea fields. The way is not always obvious without any signs but it seems like you can a broad range of the paths up the hill toward the forest top. If in doubt, the locals will point you the way towards the waterfall. A possible starting point is the path going uphill from road opposite of Pedro Tea Estate. As you only find shade right around the falls you may want to avoid the walk in the midday heat.

Great walk in emerald green tea fields. Some really nice village views as well at the top. Some locals chilling in the woods, very tranquil. Note that part of San Pedro estate is also called Lovers Leap, and we got confused and paid to enter the factory. However the factory tour was really good, nice and detailed, much better than another (Bluefield) factory we visited that day. The flavoursome hot cup'a'tea at the end of our walk was also worth paying the tea factory fee.

We were a set of 12 schoolmates catching up every year wher we spent our December vacation in the hills last year. After going to the Gregory`s lake,race course arease we decided to climb lovers leap . Well it was a long journey climbing upwards, but after all that effort, it was a pretty calm area at the top. be careful . your legs might get frozen at the water fountain right at the top.
This was a sheer drop to the sea ! Very peaceful and tranquil surrounds. If you have the time, well worth a visit. Larry & A ( Melbourne- Australia)
i am living very close to the falls. i never get bored of it any day. i walk to the falls more often, to make myself peace and calm.. welcome . drop me a message if you need any free assistance.

I am so glad we went on this walk, it was so beautiful walking along this orangey-redish road along the tea plantation. Also the waterfall is quite beautiful, more so than the Horton Plains one in my opinion. There were no tea pickers to be seen though, probably because it was Sunday. We did go a bit off the usual route and ended up being harassed by this little boy for money. 'Money pleeeese' he was saying constantly. When we did not give him any he started trowing rocks at us. Thank God for this older boy who stopped him and came to apologize and said 'that a very bad boy'.
Walked to this after visiting Predo Tea Factory.  A lovely stroll and well worth it the Falls are very pretty.
nice walk along the tea plantation. not too crowded. the waterfall is nice and peaceful with nice views.

I didn't take any tours for my tea visits so after Pedro Estate so I walked up to Lover's Leap. it's just 30 rupees by bus from down town Nuwera Eliya so it was good. The best part was the walk to the waterfalls through the villages, tea-pickers working and the greens! It was chilly so it was a perfect time to hike up while others take tuktuk. The kids were a bit pushy with pens and money though. Even a few tea-pickers as well. But still the walk was wonderful. The waterfall itself was lovely as well. I spent time on the path below so I could see it's height very well.
This waterfall is worth a look ,The views through the plantations are beautiful, and the falls are beautiful.

We stumbled across this waterfal on a 10km wander arund Nuwara Eliya (we actually had it on our list of things to see anyways!!). We opted for the more difficult route of climbing up the rocks to get to the base of the fall- but you can walk another way which is a gravelly path. Very nice to sit at the bottom and reflect on our day!
This waterfall is worth a look, there are so many around Sri Lanka but this was a nice one with plenty of monkeys about to keep you entertained.

the walk to the waterfall is quite steep and can be a bit slippery when wet. the view from the waterfall is lovely but the waterfall its self was nothing to write home about. i also wouldn't suggest a swim as its cold. the best time to go is in the morning as the view is clear and the weather will be on your side.
this is a nice place to have a walk. It doesn't take a lot of hiking to get there, it is easy to do with small children. The views through the plantations are beautiful, and the falls are beautiful.
It is nice. Stop for photos; enjoy the views; water falling sound is great. Nice place. Nice place nice place too

Starts off with a picturesque walk up to the falls.  The main footpath takes you fairly close to the water but if you look carefully there's an alternative path (lower down from the main footpath) that takes you right to the base of the falls. Perfect spot to sit in the sun and admire the views whilst feeling the spray from the falls on your back.
